description: From Latin īnsinuō (“to push in, creep in, steal in”), from in (“in”) + sinus (“a winding, bend, bay, fold, bosom”).

verbs.description: insinuate (third-person singular simple present insinuates, present participle insinuating, simple past and past participle insinuated)

entries.meaning: To hint; to suggest tacitly (usually something bad) while avoiding a direct statement.
examples: She insinuated that her friends had betrayed her.

entries.meaning: (rare) To creep, wind, or flow into; to enter gently, slowly, or imperceptibly, as into crevices.
examples: Water will insinuate itself into Flints through certain imperceptible Cracks

entries.meaning: (figurative, by extension) To ingratiate; to obtain access to or introduce something by subtle, cunning or artful means.
examples: Nanny didn't so much enter places as insinuate herself; she had unconsciously taken a natural talent for liking people and developed it into an occult science.
